text:
(a) Describe the solar system.
(b) Outline four characteristics each of the following planets:
(i) Pluto; (ii) Mercury
correct_answer:
(a) Describe the solar system. The solar system is made up of the sun and its nine planets with their satellites. The planets are: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune, Pluto. The sun is at the centre of the system and all the planets revolve round the sun in elliptical orbits. The sun is the source of light and energy for all the planets. The planets shine only by reflected light from the sun, Of the planets, Mercury is the closest and hence the hottest of the planets. It is the smallest planet while the largest planet is Jupiter. Pluto is the farthest from the sun and hence the coldest of the planets. Saturn has a unique feature of three rings.
(b) Characteristics of Planets(i) Pluto(a) It is the coldest(b) It is the farthest(c) Has the longest orbit round the sun(d) Has no satellite(e) Takes 247 years to complete one revolution round the sun.
(ii) Mercury(i) It is the smallest(ii) It is the closest to the sun(97,600,000km)(iii) It is the hottest(iv) It has no satellite(v) Does not support life because of heat(vi) Takes 88 days to revolve round the sun.

text:
(a) Describe the formation of (i) Erosional plains, (ii) Dissected plateau 
(b) Highlight two advantages and two disadvantages of plains.
correct_answer:
(a)(i) Formation of erosional plains.They are formed by agents of denudations such as rivers, wind, rain and ice. Irregular surface are often smoothened out to form plains. Different types of plain results from agents of denudation and refers to as pereplains while those fashioned by wind as agent of denudation are called pediplains. In arid regions and semi arid regions, wind deflation lowers level of land to form extensive plains whereas in glaciated regions, glaciers and ice sheets. scour and level the land to form ice — scoured plains.
(ii) Formation of Dissected plateaux.This is a product of weathering and denudation. It is the wearing down of extensive plateau by wind, water, rain and ice. This action creates narrow deep valleys in the plateau described as dissected plateau. Very good examples are: The Scottish highlands, the Jos Plateau etc. In dry areas, corrosion by rivers and abrasion by wind dissect the plateau resulting into mesas and buttes.
(b) Advantages of plains;(i) Rich sources of minerals(ii) provide fertile agricultural lands(iii) centres of population concentration(iv) plains are good for settlement(v) favour communication lines - roads and railways(vi) favour growth of pasture and so encourage animal rearing(vii) concentration of industries(viii) flood plains of rivers favour development of ports.
Disadvantages of plains(a) Not a good defence centre(b) May be waterlogged(c) Liable to flooding especially delta areas(d) May be barren e.g outwash plains in some parts of The Netherlands.(e) May present problem to communication especially when flooded .

(b) Types of Environmental Intervention(i) Natural Intervention: These include the following:(a) Earthquake(b) Vulcanicity(c) Drought(d) Flooding(e) Hurricane(f) Desert encroachment(g) Tectonic movement(h) Climatic changes(i) Sea level changes

(c) Wide spread destruction
(d) Extinction of aquatic life e.g drought results in drying up the water and this wi!I lead to the extinction of water animals

(b) Effects of latitude on the climate of Africa(a) Temperature decreases with altitude at an average rate of 6.5°C for approximately 1000m of vertical ascent
(b) High altitude area experience high amount of rainfall because of orographic effect
(c) In high altitude areas like Jos, there is little air to distribute the heat, hence cooler climate
(d) High altitude areas have less dust and water vapour and so allow the heat to escape rapidly
(e) On the windward side, rainfall is higher than the surrounding areas whereas on the leeward side, the rainfall is either scanty or low
(f) Since the atmosphere is heated by conduction, area close to the earth's surface are thus warmer
(g) Nairobi and Mombasa, for instance, are almost on the same latitude but Nairobi in a higher latitude (1675m) has lower mean annual temperature than Mombasa (1600m)
